abstract.text: Background: The severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is the 51 cause of a worldwide rapidly spreading illness, Coronavirus Disease 2019 .

Patients fed enterally and parenterally at home are exposed to the same risk of infection as the 53 general population, but more prone to complications than others. Therefore the guidance for 54 care-givers and care-takers of these patients is needed. 55 Methods: The literature search identified no relevant systematic reviews or studies on the 56 subject. Therefore a panel of 21 experts from 13 home medical nutrition (HMN) centres in 57 Poland was formed. Twenty-three key issues relevant to the management of SARS-CoV-2 58 infection or COVID-19 in the HMN settings were identified and discussed. Some statements 59 diverge from the available nutrition, surgical or ICU guidelines, some are based on the best 60 available experience. Each topic was discussed and assessed during two Delphi rounds 61 subsequently. Statements were graded strong or weak based on the balance between benefit 62 and harm, resource and cost implications, equity, and feasibility. 63 Results: the panel issued 23 statements, all of them were graded strong. Two scored 85.71% 64 agreement, eleven 95.23%, and ten 100%. The topics were: infection control, enrolment to 65 HMN, logistics and patient information. 66 Conclusions: the position paper present pragmatic statements for HMN to be implemented in 67 places without existing protocols for SARS-CoV-2 pandemic. They represent the state of 68 knowledge available at the moment and may change should new evidence occurs. 69 70 71 72 73 74

They require specialized care and increased attention. 85 Over last few weeks some organisations and societies have issued statements on the infection 86 control, screening and diagnosis in the general population, such as surgery or ICU, however, 87 no information on HMN patients has ever been published [5] [6] [7] [8] . 88 To improve this situation, a panel of Polish HMN experts decided to prepare and publish 89 statements that can be used during the everyday care of HMN patients, being fully aware that 90 most of these have not been validated. Nonetheless, the main aim was to pragmatically 91 implement nutritional care in HMN individuals to improve patient care in order to cope with 92 the current crisis. Twenty-three key issues relevant to the management of SARS-CoV-2 infection or COVID-19 123 in the HMN settings were identified and discussed.

TABREF0.text: b. only the patient and caregiver are allowed to be present during the visit Should the visit take place at the Nutrition Clinic, it should be precisely scheduled in order to reduce the waiting time to minimum.Nutritional access: Type, local condition (redness, pain, etc.), patency, tunnel leakage, swelling, risk assessment of catarrhal infection Available: dressing agents, disinfectant access, saline solution for flushing Questions to determine the health status: Feeling unwell, fever, chills, weakness Self-reliance Urination, passing of stools Stoma, fistulas, difficulties in breathing, Other alarming symptoms Conlusions: Herein, we publish a pragmatic set of statements for the delivery of HMN in time of SARS-CoV-2 pandemic. In the protocol, some procedures diverge from the available nutrition guidelines. Some discrepancies appeared due to specific settings of HMN patients and the environment. The latter include shortage of staff, increased daily workload, and need to reduce contact with patients infected with SARS-CoV-2. Authors hope that present statements can become pragmatic guidelines for HMN and to be implemented in places without existing protocols for SARS-CoV-2 pandemic. They represent the state of knowledge available at the moment and may change should new evidence occurs.
